title: Do army surgeon carry firearms? - Quora

response.answer_text: I carried a pistol throughout Desert Storm and was handed a rifle when I was riding shotgun in our convoy. Medical personnel are non-combatants which means that we cannot carry offensive weapons (like a bayonet, for some reason, but a K-Bar was OK) and we could only use the weapons in defense of our patients. I shot expert on the rifle and pistol every time we qualified and before my unit (a field hospital, although later on I went to a combat stress unit) went over, we trained in firearms including night time shooting. We were expected to help defend the logistics base in case of attack. We also had to account for every cartridge (all seven) that we were issued. In non-combat situations medical personnel are not armed, there is no reason for it even though physicians in my specialty is killed more often than other doctors. Psychiatrists the Most Common Victims of Physician Homicide

Yes. Medical personnel are trained in firearms. In 2015, I spent 2 hours providing remedial/refresher training on the M9 pistol to a psychiatrist who was a US Navy Commander, he was a reservist who had just been ordered to Active Duty and was in his way to Afghanistan. The Battalion Surgeon in an Infantry Battalion knows how to shoot a rifle.

I have spent many years in hospital units. Once a year we all went to the weapons range - doctors, nurses, medics, everyone. I regularly qualified as Expert with the M1911A1 .45 automatic. My recordwith the M-16 was not quite as good, though I often qualified as Sharpshooter.
